properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A developing low pressure system is set to affect the southern Kivalliq beginning on Thursday. As the low approaches, light snow and strong southerly winds gusting up to 70 km/h will begin in Arviat, Rankin Inlet and Chesterfield Inlet on Thursday morning. This is expected to bring blowing snow with poor visibility lasting for a few hours. The winds will then switch to the northwest and are expected to bring blizzard conditions with near zero visibility lasting until Friday morning. In Baker Lake, winds are expected to rapidly increase to 50 km/h gusting to 70 on Thursday morning from the northwest. This combined with light snow will create blizzard conditions with poor visibility lasting until Friday morning. This low will continue to push East and create further blowing snow events for Coral Harbour and Kinngait on Friday. ### Poor weather conditions may contribute to transportation delays. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-25T01:33:38-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-24T09:34:38-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4074558257.2021
Area: Baker Lake, Arviat, Rankin Region including Whale Cove, Chesterfield Inlet
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong northwesterly winds gusting to 70 km/h combined with falling snow will bring near-zero visibilities in blowing snow to Sanirajak. Blizzard conditions are expected to develop this evening and end Wednesday morning. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-24T18:58:55-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-24T02:59:55-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0815810111.2021
Area: Sanirajak
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Extreme wind chill values between minus 55 and minus 65 today. These extreme wind chill values will persist through to the end of the week. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for this morning. What: Snow, heavy at times. Total amounts of 10 to 15 cm are expected by early this afternoon. The highest amounts are expected along and south of the Highway 17 corridor. Where: Southern portions of Algoma District including Sault Ste. Marie and Elliot Lake. This includes sections of the following highways: - Highway 17 - Highway 129 - Highway 108 When: Through to early this afternoon. The heaviest snowfall is expected from 6:00 A.M. EST to 10:00 A.M. EST. Actions: Motorists should allow extra time to reach their destination. If visibility is reduced while driving, slow down, watch for tail lights ahead and be prepared to stop. Discussion: A potent Alberta Clipper will track across central Lake Huron today bringing heavy snow. Accumulating snow will cause poor driving conditions, and impact the commute this morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-24T21:29:10-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-24T10:18:10-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3811965232.2021
Area: Sault Ste. Marie - St. Joseph Island, Elliot Lake - Ranger Lake, Blind River - Thessalon
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for today. What: Snow, heavy at times. Total amounts of 10 to 15 cm are expected by this evening. Where: Regions along the northeastern shore of Georgian Bay east through Algonquin to the Ottawa River. This includes sections of the following highways: -Highway 69 -Highway 400 -Highway 11 -Highway 17 When: Snow will continue until this evening. Actions: Motorists should allow extra time to reach their destination. If visibility is reduced while driving, slow down, watch for tail lights ahead and be prepared to stop. Discussion: An Alberta Clipper will track across central Lake Huron today bringing heavy snow and accumulations of 10-15 cm. Accumulating snow will cause poor driving conditions and impact travel. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-25T07:44:37-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-24T15:45:37-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3241207069.2021

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for this morning and afternoon. What: Snow, heavy at times. Total amounts of 10 to 15 cm are expected by early this evening. The highest amounts are expected along and south of the Highway 17 corridor. Where: Greater Sudbury, North Bay, Manitoulin Island, and Killarney. This includes sections of the following highways: - Highway 17 - Highway 69 - Highway 11 - Highway 6 When: This morning through to early this evening. The heaviest snowfall is expected from 10:00 A.M. EST to 2:00 P.M. EST. Actions: Motorists should allow extra time to reach their destination. If visibility is reduced while driving, slow down, watch for tail lights ahead and be prepared to stop. Discussion: A potent Alberta Clipper will track across central Lake Huron today bringing heavy snow. Accumulating snow will cause poor driving conditions, and impact travel throughout the day. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-25T02:20:40-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-24T10:21:40-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4293065164.2021

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring in some locations. A ridge of high pressure over NWT combined with a low pressure system in the Gulf of Alaska will generate strong easterly winds near the Richardson Mountains late Wednesday into Thursday. These winds will give reduced visibilities in blowing snow. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #YTStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-25T03:56:53-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-24T11:57:53-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0452536401.2021
Area: Dempster
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Smog Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: High concentrations of fine particulates are expected and will result in poor air quality. High concentrations of pollutants are expected to continue until tomorrow morning. ### Smog especially affects asthmatic children and people with respiratory ailments or heart disease. It is therefore recommended that these individuals avoid intense physical activity outdoors until the smog warning is lifted. Additional information: To learn more about the Info-Smog program, go to Environment Canada’s website at www.canada.ca/info-smog-program. For air quality indexes in Quebec, visit the website of the Ministère de l'Environnement et de la Lutte contre les changements climatiques at www.iqa.environnement.gouv.qc.ca/contenu/index_en.asp. For the air quality index in Montréal, visit the Réseau de surveillance de la qualité de l’air de la Ville de Montréal’s website at www.rsqa.qc.ca (french only). To learn more about the effects of smog on your health in Québec, visit the Ministère de la Santé et des Services sociaux’s website at www.quebec.ca/en/health. You can also visit the Direction régionale de santé publique du CIUSSS du Centre-Sud-de-l’Île-de-Montréal at www.santemontreal.qc.ca/en/public. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2021-02-24T17:27:55-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the Ministère de l'Environnement et de la Lutte contre les changements climatiques, the Ministère de la Santé et des Services sociaux, the Direction régionale de santé publique du CIUSSS du Centre-Sud-de-l’Île-de-Montréal, the City of Montréal, 2021-02-24T01:29:55-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1747114968.2021
Area: Louiseville area, Matawin - Mauricie National Park area, Lac-aux-Sables area, Shawinigan area, Sainte-Anne-de-la-Pérade area, Trois-Rivières area, Portneuf area, Valcartier - Stoneham area, Québec area, Côte-de-Beaupré - L'Île d'Orléans area, Bellechasse area, Lévis area, Saint-Lambert area, Lotbinière area, Lac-Etchemin area, Sainte-Marie-de-Beauce area, Saint-Georges-de-Beauce area, Montmagny - Saint-Jean-Port-Joli area, Saint-Fabien - Saint-Pamphile area

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected. An intense weather system will generate strong southeast winds across the north and central coasts as well as Haida Gwaii today. The southeast winds will peak at speeds of 80 to 100 km/h across Haida Gwaii this afternoon followed by the north and central coasts this evening. After the system passes through, the southeast winds will shift to west winds with gusts up to 70 km/h overnight and then rise to westerly 90 km over most of Haida Gwaii and the North Coast on Thursday morning. ### Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-25T04:58:53-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-24T12:59:53-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3275567578.2021
Area: Haida Gwaii, Central Coast - coastal sections, North Coast - coastal sections
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of about 15 cm is expected. A Pacific frontal system will spread snow to Pine Pass tonight. The snow will be heaviest tonight. The snow will ease to flurries on Thursday. Total snowfall amounts of 15 cm are expected. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-25T03:50:23-00:00

Area: Highway 97 - Pine Pass

properties.Title: Freezing Drizzle Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Areas of freezing drizzle are expected or occurring. Locations: northeastern Newfoundland. Time span: continuing into this afternoon. Remarks: Conditions are expected to improve somewhat this afternoon as the freezing drizzle mixes with or changes to flurries. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing drizzle advisories are issued when drizzle falling in sub-zero temperatures is expected to freeze on contact, and over time create icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-02-24T21:59:08-00:00
